data.title: Correct the Student’s Sentences
data.statement:
You are a teacher. Your task is to check whether each student’s sentence ends with the correct punctuation.

Rules:

1) If a sentence begins with a question word {{how}}, {{where}}, {{when}}, {{why}}, {{who}} or {{what}}, regardless of whether it is written in uppercase or lowercase, then it must end with {{?}} .
Otherwise, the sentence must end with {{.}} .

2) Each sentence that follows the rule is deemed correct.

3) At the end, print the score in the format:
[[X]]{{/}}[[N]]
where [[X]] is the number of correct sentences and [[N]] is the total number of sentences.

4) If a sentence is wrong, print its corrected version on a new line (print only the correct versions of those sentences that are wrong).

testCases.title: Multiple Sentences (test)
testCases.testIn:
7
When is the exam?
He studies daily.
Who is your teacher?
I am bored?
How are you feeling.
Where do you live.
What are your hobbies.
testCases.testOut:
3/7
I am bored.
How are you feeling?
Where do you live?
What are your hobbies?

testCases.title: Multiple Sentences (validator)
testCases.testIn:
6
What is your name.
She is a doctor?
Why are you crying.
How did you get here.
Where is your friend?
When are your exams?
testCases.testOut:
2/6
What is your name?
She is a doctor.
Why are you crying?
How did you get here?

testCases.title: Case Insensitive (test)
testCases.testIn:
8
where are they.
who are you?
i am good.
what are you upto.
why am i here?
when is your birthday.
i do not feel good?
how did you become a freelancer.
testCases.testOut:
3/8
where are they?
what are you upto?
when is your birthday?
i do not feel good.
how did you become a freelancer?

testCases.title: Case Insensitive (validator)
testCases.testIn:
8
where are they?
who are you.
i am good?
what are you upto?
why am i here.
when is your birthday?
i do not feel good.
how did you become a freelancer?
testCases.testOut:
5/8
who are you?
i am good.
why am i here?

testCases.title: Extra Checks (test)
testCases.testIn:
4
Whoever knows the answer is a genius?
Wherever you go I will go with you.
You know how to get there.
This is where I live?
testCases.testOut:
2/4
Whoever knows the answer is a genius.
This is where I live.

testCases.title: Extra Checks (validator)
testCases.testIn:
4
Whoever knows the answer is a genius.
Wherever you go I will go with you?
You know how to get there?
This is where I live.
testCases.testOut:
2/4
Wherever you go I will go with you.
You know how to get there.

testCases.title: Mixed Casing (test)
testCases.testIn:
6
Whoever Knows The Answer Is A Genius?
wHEREVER yOU gO i wILL Go With You.
yOu KnOw HoW tO gEt ThErE.
wHERE aRE THEY.
WhO arE You?
HeLLo bRo?
testCases.testOut:
3/6
Whoever Knows The Answer Is A Genius.
wHERE aRE THEY?
HeLLo bRo.

testCases.title: Mixed Casing (validator)
testCases.testIn:
6
Learning New Things Every Day Is Fun.
practice Makes You Better Every Time.
sPoRtS aRe GoOd FoR hEaLtH.
wHERE aRE THE pEOple.
WhO arE You tALKIng TO?
i aM AWEsome?
testCases.testOut:
4/6
wHERE aRE THE pEOple?
i aM AWEsome.

data.constraints:
1 ≤ [[N]] ≤ 10
Each sentence contains only letters and spaces, except for the last character, which will either be {{.}} or {{?}}.
Sentences will always have more than one word.
data.stubGenerator:
read N:int
loop N read sentence:string(1000)
write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1>>: An integer [[N]], the number of sentences.
<<Next [[N]] lines>>: Each line contains a sentence.
data.outputDescription:
<<Line 1>>: The score in the form [[X]]{{/}}[[N]].
<<Next lines>>: The corrected version of all wrong sentences (if any), each on its own line, in the order given in the input.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You are a teacher. Your task is to check whether each student’s sentence ends with the correct punctuation.

Rules:

1) If a sentence begins with a question word how, where, when, why, who or what, regardless of whether it is written in uppercase or lowercase, then it must end with ? .
Otherwise, the sentence must end with . .

2) Each sentence that follows the rule is deemed correct.

3) At the end, print the score in the format:
X/N
where X is the number of correct sentences and N is the total number of sentences.

4) If a sentence is wrong, print its corrected version on a new line (print only the correct versions of those sentences that are wrong).
Input
Line 1: An integer N, the number of sentences.
Next N lines: Each line contains a sentence.
Output
Line 1: The score in the form X/N.
Next lines: The corrected version of all wrong sentences (if any), each on its own line, in the order given in the input.
Constraints
1 ≤ N ≤ 10
Each sentence contains only letters and spaces, except for the last character, which will either be . or ?.
Sentences will always have more than one word.
Example
Input
1
He is my friend.
Output
1/1
